item.title: Human Computer raises $5.7 million in funding round
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamedeveloper.com/business/human-computer-raises-5-7-million-in-funding-round

Image via Human Computer.

Independent studio Human Computer recently raised $5.7 million in seed funding.

The round was led by venture firm Makers Fund. a16z and ex-AirBnB COO Belinda Johnson provided further investment, bringing the developer's total funding to $7.7 million. It's the latest burst of funding for the industry this week, preceded by Pragma raising $12.75 million and a $150 million UA fund from Tilting Point.

Based in San Francisco, Human Computer was founded in 2024 by creative director Alex Schleifer and gameplay director Eliot Garcia Weisberg. Both previously worked together at AirBnB and Universal Entities, another indie studio Schliefer founded in 2020.

A "broad portfolio" for Human Computer

According to the announcement, this new team has a "broad portfolio of games" it's developing which "explore unique gameplay mechanics for the current-generation of consoles, PC and mobile devices." Its debut title will launch in Q4 2025.

"Rather than chasing endless content or massive open worlds, we're focused on creating contained, meaningful experiences that push creative boundaries," the Human Computer website reads. It later mentions the use of "emerging technologies" without specifying what those are, or how it plans to use them to "enhance human creativity, and enable new forms of storytelling."

Related:Report: Assassin's Creed maker Ubisoft could create new IP unit to court major investors

In the funding announcement, Schleifer considered his studio's upcoming work to be "triple-I indie games that combine high production value with efficient development that respects players’ time."

About the Author

Contributing Editor, GameDeveloper.com

A Kansas City, MO native, Justin Carter has written for numerous sites including IGN, Polygon, and SyFy Wire. In addition to Game Developer, his writing can be found at io9 over on Gizmodo. Don't ask him about how much gum he's had, because the answer will be more than he's willing to admit.

item.title: Report: Assassin's Creed maker Ubisoft could create new IP unit to court major investors
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamedeveloper.com/business/report-assassin-s-creed-maker-ubisoft-could-create-new-ip-unit-to-court-major-investors

Ubisoft is reportedly looking to create a new business unit that will hold major intellectual properties including Assassin's Creed.

As reported by Bloomberg, the French publisher is contemplating selling a minority stake in the new entity to investors in France and overseas—including Chinese conglomerate Tencent.

The report chimes with past rumors that indicated Ubisoft majority shareholders the Guillemot family were considering partnering with Tencent for a buyout.

People familiar with the situation claim Ubisoft has asked for preliminary bids to be submitted this month. They believe Ubisoft is hoping the new unit will receive a higher valuation than the main company.

Tencent previously purchased a $300 million stake in core Ubisoft shareholder Guillemot Brothers Limited, which is operated by Ubisoft's founding family and holds roughly 20 percent of the company's voting rights and 15 percent of its share capital.

When approached for comment by Bloomberg, Ubisoft directed the publication to the company’s quarterly earnings report.

During that fiscal briefing, Ubisoft told investors it would take "decisive steps" to reshape its business while continuing to "drive significant cost reductions" and improve the quality of its release slate.

The company also confirmed it appointed advisors to "review and pursue various transformational strategic and capitalistic options to extract the best value for stakeholders."

Related:Zenless Zone Zero actors recast amid ongoing SAG-AFTRA strike

"This process will be overseen by the independent members of the Board of Directors. Ubisoft will inform the market in accordance with applicable regulations if and once a transaction materializes," explained the company in January.

"Operationally, the company will continue to drive significant cost reductions, together with a highly selective approach to investments, and now expects to exceed €200 million ($206 million) in reduction of its fixed cost base by FY2025-26 vs. FY2022-23 on an annualized basis."

About the Author

News Editor, GameDeveloper.com

Game Developer news editor Chris Kerr is an award-winning journalist and reporter with over a decade of experience in the game industry. His byline has appeared in notable print and digital publications including Edge, Stuff, Wireframe, International Business Times, and PocketGamer.biz. Throughout his career, Chris has covered major industry events including GDC, PAX Australia, Gamescom, Paris Games Week, and Develop Brighton. He has featured on the judging panel at The Develop Star Awards on multiple occasions and appeared on BBC Radio 5 Live to discuss breaking news.
